DOC.TEXT: The stock market edged upward today, aided what analysts described as yearend ``bargain hunting.'' The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 1.92 to 2,693.05 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 701 up, 483 down and 531 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 44.38 million shares at midmorning. Traders appeared to be shopping warily among recently depressed stocks, hoping that the market will gather strength after the pressure of tax selling is lifted with the arrival of the new year. At the same time, however, the rally bid was faced with an obstacle in the form of the Commerce Department's report that new factory orders for durable goods rose 5.1 percent last month. That increase contrasted sharply with advance estimates of little or no change in orders for relatively high-priced, long-lasting goods. The suggestion it carried of unexpectedly brisk economic activity helped push interest rates higher in the credit markets. Caterpillar dropped 1{ to 56[ on top of a 1~-point loss Thursday, when the company reduced its earnings projection for the fourth quarter. Campbell Soup fell 3| to 53[. Recent takeover speculation about the stock faded a bit after a statement late Wednesday by three members of the company's controlling Dorrance family that they were committed to keeping it independent. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .40 to 190.90. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .13 at 369.68.
